When part of bigger component
If a hyperlink is placed by itself and is part of a bigger components which itself is
clickable, it does not have to be underlined, but should be emphasised in bold text
style. The key here is that the whole area should be designed in a way that it
compliments the hyperlink and feels clickable. Typically, it should be accompanied by a
directional icon - such as arrow or chevron - as an additional affordance.

Opening a new tab
You shouldn't make links open a new tab unless your user research on your system
indicates that doing so leads to a better experience. The loss of context from moving to
a new tab can be considered an accessibility issue. While opening a tab on a desktop
browser is usually fairly clear, most of our users are on mobile devices where tabs are
typically less visible. Opening a new tab also breaks that tabs back button, which stops
users from easily returning to your system.
Forcing a new tab is generally only useful if either the user will need to refer to the
contents of that tab to complete a task in the first, or if you want to make sure that a
user doesn't leave a flow in the middle. In both situations, you should carefully consider
whether there might be an alternative (and more mobile-friendly) approach.
Linking to external sites
You do not need to use an icon to indicate that a link will take a user to a different site.
Users often misunderstand these icons to mean “Opens in new tab”, and we do not
recommend that behaviour unless your research demonstrates that it will improve the
user experience.
If it's important that your users are warned about a change in site (or other context, for
example a change in language), then this should ideally be written as text. For
accessibility reasons this notification should form part of the link rather than being
placed afterwards.
Mobile native
Provide adequate clickable area
In mobile native design, in most cases, it's recommended to provide a larger clickable
area than a hyperlink in a body text can offer. You might want to limit the use of
hyperlinks to a minimum. It's better to propose the associated actions either in a List or
as Buttons. When the hyperlink is a stand-alone Ul element, use a tertiary button
instead.
However, there are cases where it cannot be easily substituted, Terms & Conditions, for
example. Skapa provides a hypertext component for such cases (link to Android and iOS
documentation).
